dataset.title: Long-term net above ground primary production of the shortgrass steppe community

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Forest, Rangeland, and Watershed Stewardship
Department of Forest, Rangeland, and Watershed Stewardship

abstract.para: The ojectives of this study are: a) Long-term monitoring of ANPP and peak-crop nitrogen yield in moderately grazed and ungrazed sites. (In conjuction with neutron probe soil water monitoring.) b) monitor temporal dynamics of life-form nitrogen concentration. Additional Objective: monitor annual nitrogen concentrations, yields, ANPP. Additional Objective: to capture a digital photograph that allows researchers to interpret biomass in g/m2 or other characteristics of the vegetation.

keywordSet.keyword: Milchunas, productivity, biomass, populations, processes, plants, vegetation

intellectualRights.para: Shortgrass Steppe (SGS) LTER data sets represent years of hard work by dedicated scientists and technicians. Please respect the effort that went into the creation of these data sets. If you plan to use the SGS LTER data sets, please follow the SGS LTER data acquisition policy outlined below. Thank you for your cooperation. 1. Before downloading data: Please send or email the SGS Data manager a short notice stating your reasons for acquiring data and a description of your publication intent. 2. Prior to Submission: Please send a copy of the report or manuscript to the principal investigator of the data. The SGS LTER should be adequately cited in any resulting publications. 3. Please Include Tag Line in Report or Manuscript: Data sets were provided by the Shortgrass Steppe Long Term Ecological Research group, a partnership between Colorado State University, United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, and the U.S. Forest Service Pawnee National Grassland. Significant funding for these data was provided by the National Science Foundation Long Term Ecological Research program (NSF Grant Number DEB-0217631). If you have any questions, please contact the Information Manager, Nicole.Kaplan@colostate.edu.

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Soil and Crop Sciences

section.title: Long-term NPP Field Sampling Protocol
section.para: Study Sites and Methods:

There are six locations: ridgetop (ridge), midslope (M-slope), swale, ESA (replicate 1, control block), Section 25 (SEC 25), and Owl Creek (OC). Make sure all are done. Each location has 15 plots. There are 3 transects with 5 plots in each transect. Plots in the grazed locations are protected by cages. Chose a random direction and distance to move the cages for the LTNPP harvest next year and re-stake the cages. Plots in the ungrazed locations are chosen randomly each year. The 3 transects are marked by rebar. Measure to the random location of the five plots along each transect.

methodStep.instrumentation: Different size bags (sizes #2-shopping bags) and coin envelopes contained in a 5 gallon bucket
Replacement tent stakes to restake cages
Digital camera and digital camera field notebook (see protocol for taking digital pictures)

section.title: Grinding and Combining Guidelines for LTER LTNPP
section.para: 1. Check bag with sample for ID information, so that the corresponding plot may be found on the Biomass List for the LTNPP.
2. Once you have located the correct plot on the Biomass List, check to see if the

plant species in the bag match up with those on the list. Keep in mind that the OPPO (cactus) has been removed from the main bag, so you will not find any OPPO in the sample bag. (If you do find any OPPO in the bag, please let Judy know.)

3. If you find any problems with the list not matching with the sampling bag, note the problem on the list and put the bag aside for Judy to deal with later. If everything matches up between the list and the bag, go ahead to step #4.
4. Separate the species for grinding according to this plan:
a. OPPO (should already be separate)
b. SPCO
c. BOGR and BUDA
d. All Others (All samples other than a, b, and c will be combined for grinding, and labeled OTHER.)

All species will not be found on every plot, but separate the ones you do find according to this plan. Total weight of the sample to be ground needs to be at least 2 grams to be put through the Wiley Mill. Samples with a total weight of less than 2 grams will be ground in the ball mill-grinding step.
5. When preparing to grind a sample, first dump the sample out onto a tray or

pan so that you can remove any foreign matter from the sample. Foreign matter may include rocks, insects, animal scat, other plant species, etc. Hopefully, most or all of the foreign matter will have been removed when the sample was weighed.

6. When you have finished checking the sample, go ahead and put it into the top of the grinder. It’s OK to bend or break the sample in order to make it fit. Always use the wooden dowel to push the sample into the grinder. Never use your hands to push the sample into the grinder! It’s a good idea to let the wooden dowel rest in the top of the grinding funnel, so that sample doesn’t “spit out” the top of the grinder after you turn the grinder on.

7. Before turning the grinder switch on, make sure that the grinder door is tightly closed and the glass “catching jar” is screwed securely onto the bottom of the grinder. Then you can secure the safety lock and turn the grinder on.

8. Quite often you will need to tamp down on the sample with the wooden dowel to force the sample to enter the grinding chamber. When the sample enters the grinding chamber the grinder will noisily chop it up. If the sample is too large or bulky, the blades may not rotate and you will not hear a grinding noise. This does not happen very often, but when it does occur it’s important to turn the grinder off right away so the motor doesn’t burn out. Then you can open up the door to the grinding chamber to free up the sample that is “stuck” with a sturdy pair of tweezers.

9. You can see the ground material coming out of the grinder into the catch jar at the bottom. When the flow of sample is down to a minimum, you can consider your sample ground and turn the grinder off.
10. Make sure to disengage the safety lock first thing, so that the grinder can not be accidentally restarted.
11. Now the grinding door may be opened and the small bits of remaining sample may be swept into the catch jar with a toothbrush. (Once again, please don’t use your hands!)

12. The ground sample may be placed in a labeled coin envelope and put aside for ball grinding in the future. If the sample is too large to fit in one coin envelope use as many coin envelopes as necessary. Label all of the envelopes as usual and then add 1 of 2, 2 of 2, etc.

13. The grinder and catching jar must be vacuumed out thoroughly between samples to prevent cross-contamination. Use a brush to turn the grinding blades and remove stuck sample if need be, not your hands.
14. Once the grinder is clean, you’re ready to start another bag of plant samples.

A digital picture must be taken of every plot before it is clipped. Use the ¼ m2 black wood frame to show the perimeter of the plot. Label the white board with the same information used on the sample bags (shown below) and place to the side of the frame. Follow the protocol for taking digital pictures (U:field season\field studies\digital pictures).

Clip at crown-level, except for shrubs. Only current year growth of shrubs are clipped that is green and has leaves, and which grows from an older, woodier branch. All live and recent dead material needs to be harvested from the plot – check your plot before moving to the next one. Old-dead is not included in the sample (the gray colored material). You can brush the old-dead material away from the clipped material with your fingers.

Plots are clipped by species. It is usually easier to first clip species other than BOGR and BUDA. There are three cactus species on the site. Only current year growth of OPPO is clipped – these are the small pads. The two “barrel” cactus are not clipped (ECVI and COVI). There are only some times when combining of species may be done. You must follow these rules when combining species.
1) The only time combining is allowed is when two species are each less than a gram (this may be a seedling, a few leaves, or one very small stem or leaf of an individual).
2) Some species are never combined even if there is only a very small quantity – these are BOGR, BUDA, SPCO, and CAHE.

3) When combining never combine forbs with shrubs, grasses with forbs, etc. Only combine grasses with grasses, forbs with forbs, and shrubs with shrubs. Envelopes that contain combined species should have codes for all species in the envelope.

Place all envelopes or small bags from each plot into the largest sample bag from that plot. Note all small mammal, ant and any other disturbances on the largest sample bag from that plot. This is usually, but not always, the BOGR bag. If there happens to be one or more large bags from one plot, keep track of them by labeling the bags “1 of 3, 2 of 3, 3 of 3”. Make sure that your writing is clear and legible and that the bags are labeled using a sharpie permanent marker.

methodStep.instrumentation: Wiley Mill, balance, and ball grinder

section.title: Protocol for Capturing Digital Images for Aboveground Biomass
section.para: Use the ladder to gain a bird?s eye view of the plot. Be sure that the wood or metal frame is delimiting the plot as accurately as possible. Run your finger along the edge of the frame and pull vegetation in that is rooted within the frame and out that is rooted outside of the frame. A photo may need to be taken of the vegetation underneath a cage. In this case, remove the stakes around the cage and place the middle frame under the cage in the center of the plot. Lift and rotate the cage one meter to the east and south and re-stake the cage. Situate yourself on the ladder in a stable position and as parallel to the plot as possible. Create a complete label for that project and plot on the white board. The label should be consistent and include the project name, date, transect, and plot or treatment description. Place the labeled white board to the right or left of the plot. Pictures should be captured at a 640 x 480 resolution. Review the picture on the screen to be sure that the image was captured. Keep track of the image # and plot label in the digital camera field book or on a data sheet that is provided. Place a pin flag with the plot and transect number or coordinates in the middle of the metal frame after you capture the image. This marks the center of the plot that was beneath a cage. It is very important to keep this record in case we need to go back and verify a digital image.

methodStep.instrumentation: Orange Field Book for Digital Camera
Black ¼ m2 wood frame (used for LTNPP, GZTX, and Cross Site plots) OR
Square meter white metal frame (used for Chart, oppo, and Bogr Removal studies)

description.para: There are six locations: ridgetop (ridge), midslope (M-slope), swale, ESA (replicate 1, control block), Section 25 (SEC 25), and Owl Creek (OC) on the Central Plains Experimental Range in Nunn, Colorado.

samplingDescription.para: There are six locations: ridgetop (ridge), midslope (M-slope), swale, ESA (replicate 1, control block), Section 25 (SEC 25), and Owl Creek (OC). Make sure all are done. Each location has 15 plots. There are 3 transects with 5 plots in each transect. Plots in the grazed locations are protected by cages. Chose a random direction and distance to move the cages for the LTNPP harvest next year and re-stake the cages. Plots in the ungrazed locations are chosen randomly each year. The 3 transects are marked by rebar. Measure to the random location of the five plots along each transect.
